poem:
Title: "Harbinger of Spring"

The curlew's subtle call,
a sweet lament while still in flight,
carried over the pastoral sprawl,
breaks dawn into day, night into light.
Facebook shares this rite,
of feathers and songs - old and new;
an omen, taking flight, 
a world to renew. 
Incantation echoed, tenuous and true,
in this fleeting world, we cling to you.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: The fields are alive with the sound of waders | Susie White On 8 February, I heard my first curlew of the year, its sweet-sad double note floating down the valley to my house. The timing was the same as last year, almost to the day, and it felt reassuring in this uncertain world. There were postings on the local Facebook page when others heard or saw their first curlew, oystercatcher, golden plover". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Country diary: The fields are alive with the sound of waders | Susie White On 8 February, I heard my first curlew of the year, its sweet-sad double note floating down the valley to my house. The timing was the same as last year, almost to the day, and it felt reassuring in this uncertain world. There were postings on the local Facebook page when others heard or saw their first curlew, oystercatcher, golden plover
